question: 16. Write \frac{{x}^{24}}{24} + 8 \cdot {3}^{11} as a product of four nonconstant polynomials with rational coefficients.
answer:
Clearing denominators, we need to factor
$$
{x}^{24} + {24} \cdot  8 \cdot  {3}^{11} = {x}^{24} + {2}^{6} \cdot  {3}^{12}.
$$
Using the sum of cubes formula, we may write
$$
{x}^{24} + {2}^{6} \cdot  {3}^{12} = {\left( {x}^{8}\right) }^{3} + {\left( {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{4}\right) }^{3} = \left( {{x}^{8} + {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{4}}\right) \left( {{x}^{16} - {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{4}{x}^{8} + {2}^{4} \cdot  {3}^{8}}\right) .
$$
Recall the Sophie Germain identity ${a}^{4} + 4{b}^{4} = \left( {{a}^{2} + 2{b}^{2} - {2ab}}\right) \left( {{a}^{2} + 2{b}^{2} + {2ab}}\right)$ . We can factor the 8th degree factor by applying the Sophie Germain identity with $a = {x}^{2}$ and $b = 3$ . Indeed, we have
$$
{x}^{24} + {2}^{6} \cdot  {3}^{12} = \left( {{x}^{4} - 6{x}^{2} + {18}}\right) \left( {{x}^{4} + 6{x}^{2} + {18}}\right) \left( {{x}^{16} - {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{4}{x}^{8} + {2}^{4} \cdot  {3}^{8}}\right) .
$$
The problem asks for one more factor; we will obtain it from the 16th degree polynomial. One way to do so is to note that the original polynomial can be factored directly using the Sophie Germain identity with $a = {x}^{6}$ and $b = 2 \cdot  {3}^{3}$ . We obtain
$$
{x}^{24} + {2}^{6} \cdot  {3}^{12} = {\left( {x}^{6}\right) }^{4} + 4 \cdot  {\left( 2 \cdot  {3}^{3}\right) }^{4}
$$
$$
= \left( {{x}^{12} - {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{3}{x}^{6} + {2}^{3} \cdot  {3}^{6}}\right) \left( {{x}^{12} + {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{3}{x}^{6} + {2}^{3} \cdot  {3}^{6}}\right) .
$$
Now, the quartic factors from before are factors of these 12th degree polynomials. We use long division to obtain
$$
\left( {{x}^{12} - {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{3}{x}^{6} + {2}^{3} \cdot  {3}^{6}}\right)  = \left( {{x}^{4} + 6{x}^{2} + {18}}\right) \left( {{x}^{8} - 6{x}^{6} + {18}{x}^{4} - {108}{x}^{2} + {324}}\right) ,
$$
and
$$
\left( {{x}^{12} + {2}^{2} \cdot  {3}^{3}{x}^{6} + {2}^{3} \cdot  {3}^{6}}\right)  = \left( {{x}^{4} - 6{x}^{2} + {18}}\right) \left( {{x}^{8} + 6{x}^{6} + {18}{x}^{4} + {108}{x}^{2} + {324}}\right) .
$$
Therefore
$$
\frac{{x}^{24}}{24} + 8 \cdot  {3}^{11} = \frac{1}{24}\left( {{x}^{24} + {2}^{6} \cdot  {3}^{12}}\right)  = \frac{1}{24}A\left( x\right) B\left( x\right) C\left( x\right) D\left( x\right) ,
$$
where
$$
A\left( x\right)  = \left( {{x}^{4} - 6{x}^{2} + {18}}\right) ;\;B\left( x\right)  = \left( {{x}^{4} + 6{x}^{2} + {18}}\right) ;
$$
$$
C\left( x\right)  = \left( {{x}^{8} - 6{x}^{6} + {18}{x}^{4} - {108}{x}^{2} + {324}}\right) ;\;D\left( x\right)  = \left( {{x}^{8} + 6{x}^{6} + {18}{x}^{4} + {108}{x}^{2} + {324}}\right) .

question: 1.2 The Helmholtz potential for a system is given as F = N{f}_{0} - N{s}_{0}\left( {T - {T}_{0}}\right) + N{\int }_{{T}_{0}}^{T}\left( \frac{{T}^{\prime } - T}{{T}^{\prime }}\right) {c}_{v}^{\text{ideal }}\left( {T}^{\prime }\right) d{T}^{\prime } - {NRT}\log \left( \frac{V}{{v}_{0}N}\right) , \tag{3.16} where {s}_{0},{T}_{0},{f}_{0} , and {v}_{0} are constants with straightforward interpretation, and {c}_{v}^{\text{ideal }}\left( T\right) is some known function of temperature. Can you find the fundamental energy relation?
answer:
We use the prescription in Table 3.1. Using the second row, we find $S\left( {T, V}\right)$ from Eqn. (3.16):
$$
S =  - {\left( \frac{\partial F}{\partial T}\right) }_{V, N} \tag{3.17}
$$
$$
= N{s}_{0} + N{\int }_{{T}_{0}}^{T}\frac{{c}_{v}^{\text{ideal }}\left( {T}^{\prime }\right) }{{T}^{\prime }}d{T}^{\prime } + {NR}\log \left\lbrack  \frac{V}{{v}_{0}N}\right\rbrack  .
$$
We used the Leibniz rule for differentiating an integral, Eqn. (A.25) in Appendix A, to obtain the second line. We find an expression for $U$ from the second column of Table 3.1:
$$
U = F + {TS}
$$
$$
= N{f}_{0} + N{s}_{0}{T}_{0} + N{\int }_{{T}_{0}}^{T}{c}_{v}^{\text{ideal }}\left( {T}^{\prime }\right) d{T}^{\prime }. \tag{3.18}
$$
If we could invert Eqn. (3.17) to find $T\left( {S, V, N}\right)$ , we could insert this expression into the upper limit of the integral in Eqn. (3.18) to obtain $U\left( {S, V, N}\right)$ , and we would have finished. However, practically speaking, the inversion is impossible without specifying ${c}_{v}^{\text{ideal }}\left( T\right)$ , and in practice is difficult to do for nearly all expressions ${c}_{v}^{\text{ideal }}\left( T\right)$ . This is as close as we can come to finding a fundamental energy relation, since Eqns. (3.17) and (3.18) are sufficient to determine $U\left( {S, V, N}\right)$ .
This example shows that it is more natural to use $F$ when $T$ and $V$ are the independent variables; the single equation (3.16) gives complete thermodynamic information, whereas we require both Eqn. (3.17) and Eqn. (3.18) in order to express the fundamental energy relation.

question: 7.1 What are the relative fluctuations of internal energy in {1\mu 1} of a simple ideal gas at standard temperature and pressure?
answer:
A simple ideal gas has average specific internal energy $\langle u\rangle  = \frac{3}{2}{RT}$ . Hence, it has specific constant-volume heat capacity ${c}_{v} = \frac{3}{2}R$ . We can use Eqn. (6.66) to estimate the relative energy fluctuations as
$$
\frac{{\sigma }_{U}}{\langle U\rangle } = \sqrt{\frac{2}{3\widetilde{N}}}
$$
$$
= \sqrt{\frac{2RT}{{3PV}{\widetilde{N}}_{\mathrm{A}}}}
$$
$$
= \sqrt{\frac{2\left( {{298}\mathrm{\;K}}\right) \left( {{0.0831}\ell .\mathrm{{bar}}/\mathrm{{mol}}\mathrm{K}}\right) }{3\left( {1\mathrm{{bar}}}\right) \left( {{10}^{-6}\ell }\right) \left( {{6.023} \times  {10}^{23}{\mathrm{\;{mol}}}^{-1}}\right) }}
$$
$$
\cong  {1.6} \times  {10}^{-9}\text{.} \tag{6.67}
$$
Hence, even for a box of volume only ${1\mu }\mathrm{l}$ , the fluctuations are in the eighth decimal place, and typically insignificant.

question: 3.2 Many binary systems are known to exhibit azeotropes. For an azeotropic mixture, the compositions of the vapor and liquid phases at equilibrium are identical, as shown in the previous example. Lewis mixtures cannot give rise to azeotropic behavior; in order to describe azeotropic mixtures, it is necessary to take into account departures from Lewis mixing in the liquid phase. A classic azeotropic mixture is provided by ethanol (1) and water (2). The azeotropic composition is approximately {x}_{1} = {0.89} . The boiling temperature of that mixture is approximately {79}^{ \circ }\mathrm{C} . The vapor pressures of ethanol and water can be determined from the following Antoine-type equations: {}^{1} {\log }_{10}{P}_{1}^{\text{sat }}\left( {kPa}\right) = {16.6758} - \frac{3674.49}{T\left( {{}^{ \circ }\mathrm{C}}\right) + {226.45}}, \tag{9.24} {\log }_{10}{P}_{2}^{\text{sat }}\left( {kPa}\right) = {16.262} - \frac{3799.89}{T\left( {{}^{ \circ }\mathrm{C}}\right) + {226.35}}. Use this information to estimate the constant A for a one-parameter Margules equation.
answer:
. For phase equilibrium between a liquid and a vapor, we write
$$
{f}_{i}^{\text{vap }} = {f}_{i}^{\text{liq }},\;i = 1,2, \tag{9.25}
$$
$$
{y}_{i}{\phi }_{i}^{\text{vap }}P = {x}_{i}{\gamma }_{i}{f}_{i}^{\text{pure }},\;i = 1,2.
$$
---
1 See Eqn. (4.49), and Table D. 4 in Appendix D for more details.
---
For simplicity, we assume that the vapor phase is an ideal gas. For an azeotropic mixture, ${x}_{1} = {y}_{1}$ ; Eqns. (9.25) therefore reduce to
$$
P = {P}_{1}^{\text{sat }}{\gamma }_{1} = {P}_{2}^{\text{sat }}{\gamma }_{2}, \tag{9.26}
$$
when we neglect the Poynting correction factor. If a one-parameter Margules equation is employed, we have
$$
\frac{A}{RT} = \frac{1}{{x}_{2}^{2} - {x}_{1}^{2}}\log \left( \frac{{P}_{2}^{\text{sat }}}{{P}_{1}^{\text{sat }}}\right) . \tag{9.27}
$$
At $T = {79}^{ \circ  }\mathrm{C}$ , we get
$$
\frac{A}{RT} = {1.062} \tag{9.28}
$$
It is important to point out that in this example we use a simple one-parameter Margules equation to describe non-ideality in the ethanol-water mixture. This mixture, however, is highly non-ideal, and more elaborate models are necessary in order to describe it over wide ranges of composition, temperature, and pressure.

question: ## EXAMPLE 9.7.3 What is the critical point of the "two-suffix Margules model"?
answer:
The solution follows from the previous example. For a given value of the constant $A$ , we find that the critical solution temperature ${T}_{\mathrm{c}}$ is given by
$$
{T}_{\mathrm{c}} = \frac{A\left( {{T}_{\mathrm{c}}, P}\right) }{2R}, \tag{9.110}
$$
and the critical composition is given by
$$
{x}_{\mathrm{c}} = \frac{1}{2}\text{.} \tag{9.111}
$$

question: 7.2 Bustamante et al. [18] measured the length of a segment of DNA under tension isothermally using an optical trap. At low tensions, they observe large fluctuations in the length, and it takes some time to find the average length. What is the size of the fluctuations in length for an isothermal polymer strand held under tension?
answer:
Using our usual mapping, we can use the results above on volume fluctuations with the substitutions: $V \rightarrow  L, - P \rightarrow  \mathcal{T}$ , and $\widetilde{N} \rightarrow  \widetilde{M}$ . The length as a function of tension is found from the free energy of the strand, Eqn. (6.62),
$$
\frac{\langle L\rangle }{\widetilde{M}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}} =  - \frac{1}{\widetilde{M}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}}{\left( \frac{\partial G}{\partial \mathcal{T}}\right) }_{T,\widetilde{M}}
$$
$$
= \coth \left( \frac{\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}}{{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T}\right)  - \frac{{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T}{\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}}\text{,} \tag{6.69}
$$
which is the inverse Langevin force law plotted in Figure 6.3. By taking the derivative of this expression, and dividing the result by the equation itself, we obtain the isothermal "compressibility"
$$
{\kappa }_{T} \mathrel{\text{:=}} \frac{1}{\langle L\rangle }{\left( \frac{\partial \langle L\rangle }{\partial \mathcal{T}}\right) }_{T,\widetilde{M}}
$$
$$
= \frac{1}{\mathcal{T}}\frac{{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T/\left( {\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}}\right)  - \left\lbrack  {\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}/\left( {{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T}\right) }\right\rbrack  {\operatorname{cosech}}^{2}\left\lbrack  {\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}/\left( {{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T}\right) }\right\rbrack  }{\coth \left\lbrack  {\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}/\left( {{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T}\right) }\right\rbrack   - {k}_{\mathrm{B}}T/\left( {\mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}}\right) }. \tag{6.70}
$$
Now we can use our results from this section, Eqn. (6.68), to find the relative magnitude of the fluctuations in length of the strand:
$$
\frac{{\sigma }_{L}\left( {T,\mathcal{T},\widetilde{M}}\right) }{\langle L\rangle } = \sqrt{\frac{{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T{\kappa }_{T}}{\langle L\rangle }}
$$
$$
= \frac{1}{\sqrt{\widetilde{M}}}\frac{\sqrt{{x}^{-2} - {\operatorname{cosech}}^{2}\left( x\right) }}{\coth \left( x\right)  - {x}^{-1}}, \tag{6.71}
$$
where $x \mathrel{\text{:=}} \mathcal{T}{a}_{\mathrm{K}}/\left( {{k}_{\mathrm{B}}T}\right)$ is the dimensionless tension. There are two things that it is worthwhile to note about this result. First, we see again that the relative magnitude depends inversely upon the square root of the number of segments in the chain, which is another specific example of the general result (the simple ideal gas was the first). Secondly, we see that there is a tension-dependent part that can make the fluctuations very large, even for long chains. To illustrate the importance of this second term, we plot it against the dimensionless tension in Figure 6.5.
In accord with observations, we see that the relative fluctuations are much larger for smaller tensions. The result is not surprising, since the average length goes to zero for no tension, but the fluctuations remain finite.
![0195e3a5-e884-7340-b59a-aeb687e08669_228_674_1543_569_365_0.jpg](images/0195e3a5-e884-7340-b59a-aeb687e08669_228_674_1543_569_365_0.jpg)
Figure 6.5 The relative magnitude of end-to-end length fluctuations in a polymer strand of $\widetilde{M}$ steps under tension $\mathcal{T}$ . When the magnitude is multiplied by the square root of the number of steps, as is done here, the result depends only on the (dimensionless) tension. From this plot, we see, for example, that, if the dimensionless tension is one, $\mathcal{T} = {k}_{\mathrm{B}}T/{a}_{\mathrm{K}}$ , the chain must be longer than 100 segments in order to attain fluctuations of less than 10%.

question: Given a volume-explicit equation of state z\left( {T, P,\left\{ {N}_{i}\right\} }\right) , find the residual partial molar Gibbs free energy.
answer:
It is easier to use the alternative definition for the residual partial molar Gibbs, Eqn. (8.31), since we already have an expression for the residual Gibbs potential, Eqn. (4.67). We start from the alternative definition
$$
\frac{{\bar{g}}_{i}^{\mathrm{R}}}{RT} = {\left( \frac{\partial }{\partial {N}_{i}}\frac{{G}^{R}}{RT}\right) }_{T, P,\left\{  {N}_{j \neq  i}\right\}  }
$$
$$
= \frac{\partial }{\partial {N}_{i}}N{\int }_{0}^{P}\left\lbrack  {z\left( {T,{P}^{\prime },\left\{  {N}_{j}\right\}  }\right)  - 1}\right\rbrack  \frac{d{P}^{\prime }}{{P}^{\prime }}
$$
$$
= {\int }_{0}^{P}\left\lbrack  {{\bar{z}}_{i}\left( {T,{P}^{\prime },\left\{  {N}_{j}\right\}  }\right)  - 1}\right\rbrack  \frac{d{P}^{\prime }}{{P}^{\prime }}, \tag{8.32}
$$
where we have introduced the quantity
$$
{\bar{z}}_{i}\left( {T, P,\left\{  {N}_{i}\right\}  }\right)  \mathrel{\text{:=}} {\left( \frac{\partial }{\partial {N}_{i}}Nz\right) }_{T, P,\left\{  {N}_{j \neq  i}\right\}  }. \tag{8.33}
$$
Using this expression, the residual partial molar Gibbs free energy can be found for any volume-explicit equation of state when the appropriate mixing rules for the parameters are known.
The results from the previous example are useful only for a volume-explicit equation of state for mixtures. More common are pressure-explicit equations of state. The analogous result for ${\bar{g}}_{i}^{\mathrm{R}}$ given $z\left( {T, V,\left\{  {N}_{i}\right\}  }\right)$ can be found from Eqn. (8.32) through a change of variable of integration from ${P}^{\prime }$ to ${V}^{\prime }$ . The result is
$$
\frac{{\bar{g}}_{i}^{\mathrm{R}}}{RT} = {\int }_{V}^{\infty }\left\lbrack  {{\left( \frac{\partial }{\partial {N}_{i}}Nz\right) }_{T, V,\left\{  {N}_{j \neq  i}\right\}  } - 1}\right\rbrack  \frac{d{V}^{\prime }}{{V}^{\prime }} - \log z. \tag{8.34}
$$
